metadata.synopsis: After being kept a prisoner in his own home for 35 years, a man (Nicholas Hope) accidentally kills his parents and escapes into the real world.

reviews: A proverbial cult classic that's as wild and unpredictable as its primitive central character. Please, watch this instead of Forrest Gump.
It's a one‑off weirdie, offputting for whole stretches but unforgettable, not for everyone but highly recommended to the discerning.
Hugely effective at best, irritating and shocking at worst, you won't ever have seen anything quite like this one.
this dark satire-cum-parable (cling)wraps itself in a quirkily beautiful aesthetic that keeps us watching even when the material is at its most repellent or alarming.
You may not understand Bubby, but damn if you won't want to take him home with you -- if only for an hour or so.
Ultimately, this dark mirror on the world provides an extraordinary panorama of humanity and the environment in the 1990s.
The success of the film is largely due to the bravura performance by Hope.
This proficient film is never less than intriguing. It may be muddled, but one can't deny its ambitions, or the integrity of Hope's performance.
The miracle of casting; with Bad Boy Bubby, Rolf de Heer plucked Nicholas Hope from obscurity and gave him the role of his acting life
A memorable, affecting and quietly exceptional tale
